Name: Alchemy
Description: An institution of higher learning.

Name: Alchemist
Description: The laboratory and home of a crafter of poisons, potions, or alchemical items.

Name: Arena
Description: A large public structure for competitions and team sports.

Name: Bank
Description: A secure building for storing valuables and granting loans.

Name: Bardic College
Description: A center for artistic learning. Education in a Bardic College also includes research into a wide-range of historical topics.

Name: Barracks
Description: A building to house conscripts, guards, militia, soldiers, or similar military forces.

Name: Black Market
Description: A number of shops with secret and usually illegal wares.

Name: Brewery
Description: A building for beer brewing, winemaking, or some similar use.

Name: Bridge
Special: Shares the space with a river or Waterwaylot
Description: Allows travel across a river or Waterway, easing transportation

Name: Bureau
Description: A large warren of offices for clerks and record-keepers working for a guild or government.

Name: Casters Tower
Description: The home and laboratory for a spellcaster.

Name: Castle
Description: The home of the settlement's leader or the heart of its defenses.

Name: Cathedral
Special: Halves Consumption increase for Promotion Edicts
Description: The focal point of the settlement's spiritual leadership.

Name: Cistern
Limit: Cannot be adjacent to a Dump, Graveyard, Stable, Stockyard, or Tannery
Special: Can share lot with another building
Description: Contains a safe supply of fresh water for the settlement.

Name: City Wall
Special: Land district border
Description: A fortification of one side of a district with a sturdy wall. The GM may allow for cliffs and other natural features to function as a City Wall for one or more sides of a district. You may construct gates through your own city wall at no cost.

Name: Dance Hall
Description: An establishment for dancing, drinking, carousing, and holding celebrations.

Name: Dump
Limit: Cannot be adjacent to House, Mansion, or Noble Villa
Description: A centralized place to dispose of refuse.

Name: Everflowing Spring
Special: Can share lot with Castle, Cathedral, Market, Monument, Park, or Town Hall
Description: A fountain built around several decanters of endless water that provides an inexhaustible supply of fresh water.

Name: Exotic Artisan
Description: The shop and home of a jeweler, tinker, glassblower, or the like.

Name: Foreign Quarter
Special: Increase the value of trade routes (see Trade Edicts) by 5% (maximum 100%)
Description: An area with many foreigners, as well as shops and services catering to them.

Name: Foundry
Special: Increase the Economy and BP earned per turn by 1 for 1 Mine connected to this settlement by a river or Road
Description: Processes ore and refines it into finished metal.

Name: Garrison
Description: A large building to house armies, train guards, and recruit militia.

Name: Granary
Special: If Farms reduce Consumption below 0, store up to 5 BP of excess production for use on a later turn when Consumption exceeds the Treasury
Description: A place to store grain and food.

Name: Graveyard
Description: A plot of land to honor and bury the dead.

Name: Guildhall
Description: The headquarters for a guild or similar organization.

Name: Herbalist
Description: The workshop and home of a gardener, healer, or poisoner.

Name: Hospital
Special: Increase Stability by 2 during plague events
Description: A building devoted to healing the sick.

Name: House
Special: The first House you build during the Improvement phase does not count against the total number of buildings you can build during the phase
Description: A number of mid-sized houses for citizens.

Name: Inn
Description: A place for visitors to rest.

Name: Jail
Description: A fortified structure for confining criminals or dangerous monsters.

Name: Library
Description: A large building containing an archive of books.

Name: Luxury Store
Description: A shop that specializes in expensive comforts for the wealthy.

Name: Magic Shop
Description: A shop that specializes in magic items and spells.

Name: Magical Academy
Description: An institution for training students in spellcasting, magic item crafting, and various arcane arts.

Name: Magical Streetlamps
Limit: Settlement must have a Cathedral, Magic Shop, Magical Academy, or Temple
Special: Can share a lot with any building or improvement
Description: Continual flame lamps that illuminate the lot.

Name: Mansion
Description: A single huge manor housing a rich family and its servants.

Name: Market
Description: An open area for traveling merchants and bargain hunters.

Name: Menagerie
Special: Increase Loyalty by 1/4 the CR of the highest-CR creature in the Menagerie
Description: A large park stocked with exotic creatures for public viewing.

Name: Military Academy
Special: Armies and commanders recruited at the settlement gain one bonus tactic (see Army Tactics)
Description: An institution dedicated to the study of war and the training of elite soldiers and officers.

Name: Mill
Special: With GM approval, you can construct a windmill at the same cost without the water district border requirement
Description: A building used to cut lumber or grind grain.

Name: Millpind
Description: A millpond is a body of water formed by damming a small river or stream, which provides power for a mill. It often doubles as a fishing lake. A millpond functions as a water border for mills.

Name: Mint
Description: A secure building where the kingdom's coinage is minted and standard weights and measures are kept.

Name: Moat
Special: Cannot be damaged by siege engines
Description: A fortification of one side of a district with an open or water-filled ditch, often backed by a low dike or embankment. The GM may allow a river or similar natural feature to function as a moat for one or more sides of a district.

Name: Monastery
Description: A cloister for meditation, study, and the pursuit of various other scholarly paths.

Name: Monument
Description: A local memorial such as a bell tower, a statue of a settlement founder, a large tomb, or a public display of art.

Name: Museum
Description: A place to display art and artifacts both modern and historical. The GM may allow the kingdom leaders to display a valuable item (such as a magic item or bejeweled statue) in the museum, increasing Fame during this display by 1 for every 10,000 gp of the item's price (maximum +5 Fame), and by an additional 1 if the item is significant to the kingdom's history.

Name: Noble Villa
Description: A sprawling manor with luxurious grounds that houses a noble's family and staff.

Name: Observatory
Description: A dome or tower with optical devices for viewing the heavens.

Name: Orphanage
Description: A place for housing and taking care of large numbers of orphans

Name: Palace
Special: You may make two special edicts per turn, but take a –2 penalty on kingdom checks associated with each special edict
Description: A grand edifice and walled grounds demonstrating one's wealth, power, and authority to the world.

Name: Park
Description: A plot of land set aside for its serene beauty.

Name: Paved Streets
Description: Brick or stone pavement that speeds transportation.

Name: Pier
Description: Warehouses and workshops for docking ships and handling cargo and passengers.

Name: Sewer System
Description: An underground sanitation system that keeps the settlement clean, though it may become home to criminals and monsters.

Name: Shop
Description: A general store.

Name: Shrine
Description: A shrine, idol, sacred grove, or similar holy site designed for worship by pious individuals.

Name: Smithy
Description: The workshop of an armorsmith, blacksmith, weaponsmith, or other craftsman who works with metal.

Name: Stable
Description: A structure for housing or selling horses and other mounts.

Name: Stockyard
Special: Farms in this hex or adjacent hexes reduce Consumption by 3 instead of 2
Description: Barns and pens that store herd animals and prepare them for nearby slaughterhouses.

Name: Tannery
Description: A structure that prepares hides and leather.

Name: Tavern
Description: An eating or drinking establishment.

Name: Temple
Description: A large place of worship dedicated to a deity

Name: Tenement
Special: Counts as House
Description: A staggering number of low-rent housing units

Name: Theater
Discount: Brothel, Exotic Artisan, Inn, Park, Tavern
Description: A venue for entertainments such as plays, operas, and concerts.

Name: Town Hall
Description: A public venue for town meetings, repository for town records, and offices for minor bureaucrats.

Name: Trade Shop
Description: A shop front for a tradesperson, such as a baker, butcher, candle maker, cobbler, rope maker, or wainwright.

Name: University
Discount: Academy, Bardic College, Library, Magical Academy, Military Academy, Museum
Description: An institution of higher learning, focusing mainly on mundane subjects but dabbling in magical theory.

Name: Watchtower
Description: A tall structure that serves as a guard post.

Name: Watergate
Description: A gate in a City Wall that allows water (such as a river, Aqueduct, or Waterway) to enter the settlement. a Watergate has underwater defenses to block unwanted access. If you construct a Watergate when you construct a City Wall, the Watergate does not count toward the limit of the number of buildings you can construct per turn.

Name: Waterfront
Limit: Adjacent to water district border, 1 per settlement
Special: halves Loyalty penalty for Taxation edicts
Description: A port for waterborne arrival and departure, with facilities for shipping and shipbuilding.

Name: Waterway
Special: Counts as water district border for adjacent buildings
Description: A river or canal occupying part of the District Grid. At the GM's option, a natural Waterway may already exist on the grid, requiring no action or BP to build. If you construct a City Wall that touches or crosses the Waterway, you must also build Watergates on the same turn.
